subject: Re: [junit] Re: Running Multiple Fixtures in junit.swingui.TestRunner

messageBody:
I wrote, quoting the JUnit Web site:

> > > "Tests need to run against the background of a known set of objects.
> > > This set of objects is called a test fixture.

Having thought about this, I have come to realize that it isn't quite
true.

For the last several months I have been working on software that
instruments Java classes. It does this by adding bytecode to the compiled
class as it is being loaded. The software that does this is tested using
JUnit. The class that is delivered by the classloader is in fact the main
"object" of the test fixture. This class is related to the Java class,
the file with the .class extension, but it is not the same. Among other
things, it is much larger :-(

It is a requirement that the instrumented classes be functionally
identical to the original classes. Many of the unit tests are there to
confirm that this is true.

Some of the classes tested are synthesized at run time, so that there is
no .java source file at all.

In other words, fixtures can include classes, although they almost always
consist only of objects. However, in my experience, the classes
that form part of the fixture are wholly distinct from the TestCase
class, although they are created in the setUp() method.

More details, should anyone be interested, on http://jxcl.sourceforge.net

(JXCL is alpha software, with two known bugs and unsophisticated report
facilities.)

Of course, someone with a pronounced and perverse sense of humor might
want to have a go at making the TestCase class itself part of the fixture.
;-)
